ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was:
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned more about different aspects of land use
I learned about the impact of zoning on constructing livable, sustainable communities.
This course gave a comprehensive overview on various topics related to land use.
I gained a great deal of insight into land use planning and the cutting edge areas worth engaging in now and in the future.

This was a very useful survey of how and where land use planning is getting done. The fact that we had lectures from a variety of practitioners meant that we could go more in depth about specific areas of land use. It also meant that we got a glimpse of what is coming next from the inside.
General walk through issues in land use
I expected to learn about a broad array of land use topics/issues with land use

narratives.question_text: How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations?
comments: Very well
It was aligned with my expectations.
The course aligned well with my expectations and often exceeded what I thought I would gain.

Expectations were largely well aligned. Kevin Dwarka's lecture exceeded expectations. He gave a great amount of context, depth, and potential. The best lectures covered these three thoroughly. Occassionallly depth was lacking.
well
The class incorporated many different and diverse topics in land use which I appreciated learning about. I also appreciated the varying perspectives of the presenters.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some presenters didn't leave much time for questions
The strength of the course is the variety of speakers who presented throughout the semester. An incorporation of class discussion would deepen the experience of the class.

There is never enough time in class. However, presenters that allowed time for questions had the most engaging presentations because of this time. We might be able to learn more from presentations and from each other if 15-ish minutes were given to discussion of speakers and their topics after guest lectures. It was very interesting to learn from practitioners in the field, but some time to debrief each presentation with each other and talk about what we thought of it would be extremely helpful.
Strengths- variety of topics, speakers from various workplaces, reasonable amount of work Weaknesses- none

A strength of the course is the fact that it is a relatively low lift as far as student effort, and the level of engagement is really defined by the individual student. Regardless of one's level of effort, by just attending seminar, you gain exposure to a wide range of land use issues in an effective way that builds over the semester.

The seminar served its purpose. Strengths were that we were introduced to a broad variety of land use subjects. The readings were also interesting, and useful to better understand some of the legal nuances and opportunities not always covered in class. It could be improved by having speakers come in from communities that have gone through comprehensive planning. Discussions could be more nuanced and informative this way.
It is a seminar with different speakers each week
The presenters often spoke for the entire class period leaving little time at the end for discussion/questions

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: I would recommend taking it, and recommend doing readings beforehand
It is a laid-back class experience and worth taking if you are interested in getting an introduction to working on sustainability issues on local levels.
Great introduction class to Land Use and city planning topics. This, or an equivalent, is a requirement for the Land Use Clinic.
Attend every lecture, engage with the speakers
I would advise students even vaguely interested in land use planning to take this course! It's a great opportunity for exposure and learning.

This is a good class for anyone interested in an introduction to land use planning. Multiple speaker's mean that you can reach out to individuals for more information if you are interested in a particular avenue. Work load is light, largely just enjoying lectures each week. But don't skimp on the readings. They are interesting, useful, and cover material not covered in class most days.
It is a great course to start learning about land use
I would advise students to engage with the presenters and to ask questions about topics you are interested in, as our class had some very insightful discussions when questions were asked.
